_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Other Chemical and Allied Products Merchant Wholesalers

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Ashland Distribution Company (Ashland) relies on numerous programs to ensure early identification of and proper response to potential emergencies, including:

-Training and drills in emergency preparedness, hazardous materials training, disaster response and control, first aid, and fire-and-rescue techniques;

-Frequent auditing of all preparedness programs, safety training and education; and

-Regular review, follow-up, and maintenance of all company operations and equipment.

Our facilities invite local fire departments and emergency responders to tour and inspect our plants, participate in joint emergency drills, and gain familiarity with our operations.  Many of our employees are members of the Local Emergency Planning Commission in their areas.  Our facilities have written emergency preparedness plans that are updated regularly.

A description of your facility and the regulated substances handled:

Ashland's Houston, TX facility is a chemical distribution warehouse.  The regulated substance arrives at the warehouse loading dock, is transferred to storage and subsequently loaded for shipment without ever opening the containers.  The regulated substances are methyl formcel (55 wt.%) and butyl formcel (40 wt.%).

The general accidental release prevention program and chemical specific prevention steps:

The Houston, TX distribution warehouse is operated in strict accordance with the USEPA prevention program requirements as well as OSHA's Process Safety Management regulation.  A written management system is in place along with written operating procedures.  Our management system procedures ensure rigorous training for operations employees, numerous management checks and balances and strict attention to changes in the operations with a thorough review and examination of potential incidents that could lead to an accidental release.  Ashland maintains a 24 hour corporate emergency reporting system that can speedily coordinate emergency response with management and quic

kly communicate key first aid or medical information to local health care providers.  

Five year accident history:

We have never had a release of methyl formcel or butyl formcel that has resulted in or could have resulted in an offsite impact.

Emergency Response Program:

The employees of the Houston, TX facility do not respond offensively to accidental releases of the regulated substance, but rely on local emergency responders when there is a need.  Our employees regularly undergo training in defensive emergency response activities.  Our facility invites the local fire department and emergency responders to tour and inspect our plant and gain familiarity with our operations.  This facility has a written emergency preparedness plan that is updated regularly.

Planned changes to improve safety:

The Houston, TX facility continually evaluates and implements employee suggestions and recommendations resulting from routine plant safety meetings, process hazard analyses and incident investigation reviews. We also make changes to improve safety based on comments and information developed within our organization and the industry.  Employees actively participate in the near-miss program.  Toward continuous improvement, we are looking at ways to minimize risk through process improvement and re-design.  The Houston facility plans to upgrade the existing fire suppression system.
